title: Rights of citizenship of certain migrants to Pakistan.
text:
Notwithstanding anything in Articles 5 and 6, a person who has after the first day of March, 1947, migrated from the territory of India to the territory now included in Pakistan shall not be deemed to be a citizen of India

Provided that nothing in this article shall apply to a person who, after having so migrated to the territory now included in Pakistan, has returned to the territory of India under a permit for resettlement or permanent return issued by or under the authority of any law and every such person shall for the purposes of clause (b) of article 6 be deemed to have migrated to the territory of India after the nineteenth day of July, 1948.
summary:
Partition also led to displacements & emigrations from India. While some left voluntarily, others were forced to leave under extenuating circumstances.

Emigrants were generally deemed to have declared their allegiance to Pakistan and denied Indain citizenship, but one exception was still allowed:
    Those who returned under a permit by a competent authority would be treated as immigrants coming after 19th July, 1948 for Art 6(b).
Art 7, therefore, does not grant citizenship rights to such returnees but simply makes permitted returnees eligible for citizenship if they registered, as req. u. Art 6(b).

March 1st, 1947 was chosen as the cutoff date as it was 'the date when the disturbances started and the exodus began' (Const Assembly Debates).
